The  proposed  Crisis  Recovery  Support  Program  (the  Program) 
will enable the Government to mitigate the adverse impact of the 
global  financial crisis.  The  Program  is  anchored  on  the  Stand-By 
Arrangement  (SBA)  with  the  International  Monetary  Fund  (IMF), 
which provides the overall framework for macroeconomic stability 
and  structural  reform.  Further,  the  Government’s  own  crisis 
mitigation  plan  will  be  the  public  expenditure  anchor  for  the 
support  from  ADB.  The  Program  has  been  formulated  in  close 
consultation  with  the  Government  and  after  an  assessment  of 
crisis impact and fiscal needs. It is part of a well-coordinated and 
concerted  donor  effort  to  respond  to  the  Government’s  urgent 
request for budget support.

II. 

RECENT MACROECONOMIC PERFORMANCE  

2. 
Pre-Crisis  Economic  Performance.  Armenia  is  a  small,  open  economy  that  relies 
heavily  on  remittances,  foreign  investment,  and  imports.  With  real  gross  domestic  product 
(GDP) increasing yearly by an average of more than 10% (Table 1), Armenia has been a stable 
and  strong  performer  in  the  region.  Much  of  the  recent  growth  was  fueled  by  the  construction 
and  mining  sectors.  The  share  of  construction  in  GDP  increased  from  9%  in  2001  to  23%  in 
2008.  Remittances  and  capital  inflows  sustained  the  construction  boom,  while  increasing 
international  commodity  prices  helped  the  mining  sector.  Remittances  also  boosted  domestic 
consumption.

Strong Commitment to Reform. Armenia has embarked on an ambitious set of 
reforms, including stimulating competition among enterprises, improvement of the business and

Construction  Slowdown.  Construction,  a  major  driving  force  behind  Armenia’s  robust 
economic growth in recent years, slowed as the demand for apartments and offices weakened. 
Since  most  FDI  was  channeled  into  construction,  the  sharp  falloff  in  FDI  since  April  2008, 
combined with the reduction in demand, slashed construction activity by 31% in the second half 
of 2008. In the first quarter of 2009, value creation in the sector was down by 22% compared 
with the same period in 2008. 
 
9.

prices  of  copper  and  molybdenum  ores,4  and  triggered  the  layoff  of  hundreds  of  sector

Large Budget Deficit and Financing Gap. Barring an unexpected, rapid reversal of the 
sharp  deterioration  in  the  economy  and  in  tax  revenues  since  last  quarter  of    2008,  it  is  clear 
that the Government budget deficit for 2009 will far exceed the AMD40 billion ($105 million; 1% 
of GDP) forecast when the budget was adopted by Parliament in November 2008. As forecast 
by  the  International  Monetary  Fund  (IMF),  9.5%  decline  in  GDP,  with  government  revenues 
declining  by  6.7%  year-on-year  from  2008  to  2009  with  corresponding  adjustments  in 
expenditure would increase the budget deficit to AMD217 billion ($564 million), or 6.5% of GDP, 
and create a financing gap of $460 million (Table 3). The budget deficit and the corresponding 
financing  gap  would  be  significantly  larger  if  the  revenues  were  to  decline  further  and 
expenditure suspensions were not made by the Government.

A. Links to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
The Government’s long-term vision is presented in detail in the Sustainable Development Program (SDP). Approved in 
October 2008, SDP is Armenia’s second Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper (PRSP II) and has three key goals covering 
the  period  2009–2021  (with  specific  medium-term  targets  for  2009–2015):  (i)  reducing  poverty  and  eliminating  extreme 
poverty;  (ii)  ensuring  human  development;  and  (iii)  deepening  economic  growth  and  accelerating  the  development  of 
lagging regions.  

The SDP builds on the considerable achievements of PRSP I. Armenia’s poverty and extreme poverty rates declined in 
2006  to  26.5%  and  4.1%  of  the  population,  respectively  (from  34.6%  and  6.4%,  respectively,  in  2004).  Inequality  also 
decreased  to  a  rate  below  the  PRSP I  goal.  Prudent  fiscal  and  monetary  policies  were  instrumental  in  maintaining 
macroeconomic  stability  and  contributing  to  poverty  reduction.  Real  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  grew  by  13.1%  per 
year  on  average  over  the  period  2003–2007,  and  inflation  averaged  3.9%  during  the  same  period,  while  social 
expenditures increased to 4.7% of GDP, well above the projected PRSP I goal of 3.0%. Increased resources to the social 
sectors  improved  the  access  to  and  quality  of  general  secondary  education,  and  have  led  to  improvements  in  overall 
utilization of  and  geographic  access to basic health services, most notably through the  free provision  of primary health 
care to the population. 

However,  economic  diversification  has  been  limited,  with  growth  performance  narrowly  based  on  remittances  and 
construction. Export performance has been disappointing, with real growth of less than 2% per annum in 2004–2007. The 
revenue-to-GDP  ratio  grew  to  a  less-than-targeted  14.5%  by  2006,  reflecting  limited  progress  in  reforming  revenue 
administration, whereas total public spending decreased by 0.7% of GDP in 2003–2007. 

The  SDP  shows  that  Armenia  plans  to  continue  its  impressive  gains  in  combating  poverty  and  inequality.  The 
Government’s anticipation of good progress, predicated on double-digit economic growth, the increase of labor income, 
private  transfers  from  abroad,  pensions,  and  the  increase  in  social  transfers  through  a  well-targeted  social  protection 
program, has become uncertain because of the sudden and severe nature of the financial crisis. 

The SDP presents an extensive and in-depth coverage of the macroeconomic framework and of macroeconomic policies. 
Projections that were fully in line with the 2009 annual budget and the medium-term expenditure framework are now in 
doubt, following a reduction in revenues and a deceleration of the economy.  

In the health sector, the SDP increased access to and quality of health-care services, and over the medium term, further 
development  of  the  primary  health-care  system  will  remain  among  the  key  priorities  in  order  to  complete  the 
transformation to a more efficient, family medicine–based system. In education, public expenditure is projected to reach 
4.5%  of  GDP  by  2021,  as  the  Government  is  committed  to  improving  the  quality  and  accessibility  of  school  education. 
Some of these interventions may have to be postponed to allow for a review of the budget. 

Perhaps the most significant new policy in the SDP is the considerable real increase in state pensions. This reflects the 
objective of providing minimum income security against poverty in old age, and the introduction of a mandatory funded 
pension pillar in 2010.a  

The Country Operations Business Plan 2008–2010 envisages support to enhance government effectiveness and help the 
Government  implement  its  innovative  governance  reforms  program.  It  also  flags  the  need  to  provide  resources  for  the 
implementation of the SDP of the Government.

I. 

RECENT MACROECONOMIC PERFORMANCE AND OUTLOOK 

FOR 2009–2010 

Armenia is now facing significant challenges following a long period of macroeconomic 
1. 
success  and  stability.  Under  the  Poverty  Reduction  and  Growth  Facility  (PRGF)  arrangement 
that  covered  the  period  2005–2008,  prudent  macroeconomic  policies  and  structural  reforms 
contributed to double digit gross domestic product (GDP) growth, low inflation, and a significant 
reduction  in  poverty  rates.  Despite  a  widening  external  current  account  deficit,  international 
reserves  continued  to  increase,  owing  to  large  foreign  exchange  inflows  and  dedollarization, 
and  external  debt  remained  low.  The  overall  fiscal  deficit  was  contained,  and  additional 
revenues  arising  from  improvements  in  tax  administration  could  be  used  to  finance 
poverty-reducing  expenditures.  Government  debt  remained  stable.  The  monetary  framework 
was strengthened, contributing, with a flexible exchange rate, to maintaining low inflation. 
 
2. 
In the first 3 quarters of 2008, growth remained strong, with GDP increasing by 10.4% 
through September. Driven by international prices and strong domestic demand, inflation rose to 
a high of 11.5% in August, and the current account deficit continued to worsen. In response to 
these signs of overheating, monetary policy was progressively tightened. 
 
The  economic  outlook  changed  abruptly  as  the  global  financial  crisis  deepened  in 
3. 
October.  Owing  to  its  relative  international  isolation,  the  financial  sector  was  not  directly 
affected.  However,  the  mining  sector  and  exports  were  severely  hit  by  the  sharp  drop  in 
international  commodity  prices,  with  many  mines  stopping  operations.  In  addition,  remittances 
and capital inflows slowed considerably, which had a major impact on the construction sector. 
As a consequence, growth came to a halt, with annual GDP growth falling to 6.8% for the year 
as a whole, and the external current account deficit rising to an estimated 12.6% of GDP. In the 
wake of falling international prices and rapidly slowing domestic demand, inflation fell to 4% in 
January 2009. 
 
4. 
Out of concerns for the impact of a crisis in confidence on financial stability, the Central 
Bank of Armenia (CBA) intervened repeatedly to stabilize the exchange rate in the last part of 
2008 and in early 2009. With expectations for a depreciation of the dram gaining strength, the 
CBA  faced  strong  pressures,  leading  to  a  rapid  decline  in  international  reserves.  With  a 
significant  amount  of  deposits  being  converted  to  foreign  currency,  and  overall  deposits 
declining slightly, banks came under pressure to reduce lending. In this context, and in line with 
the  changed  inflation  outlook,  the  CBA  eased  monetary  policy,  cutting  the  policy  rate  from 
7.75% in November 2008 to 6.75% in February 2009. 
 
5. 
As a result of the commodity price shock and our attempt to preserve financial stability, 
we  missed  most  of  the  end-December  targets  under  the  PRGF  arrangement.  Due  to 
unexpectedly large foreign currency sales, both the end-2008 targets for international reserves 
and net domestic assets of the CBA were missed. In addition, the target on net banking system 
credit  to  the  government,  as  well  as  that  on  the  underlying  fiscal  balance,  was  also  missed. 
Other targets under the program were respected.

We are committed to return to a flexible exchange rate regime in the immediate future. 
9. 
Since  the  deepening  of  the  global  financial  crisis  in  October  2008,  intervention  has  been 
necessary  to  prevent  a  crisis  of  confidence  that  was  threatening  the  stability  of  the  financial

October 2008,  our  exchange  rate  misalignment  has  increased  significantly,  owing  to  the 
worsening  economic  outlook  and  the  currency  depreciation  experienced  by  many  of  our  trade 
partners. We expect the exchange rate to move to a value in line with its fundamentals when we 
return  to  a  floating  regime.  When  normal  market  functioning  is  restored,  our  exchange  rate 
policy will be a managed float with no predetermined path. We are committed to intervening only 
to smooth excessive market volatility and to increase international reserves.

Fiscal  policy  will  support  macroeconomic  stability,  while  allowing  for  continued  public 
13. 
investment  and  protection  of  social  services.  To  this  end,  we  intend  to  limit  the  overall  fiscal 
deficit in 2009 to around 3% of GDP, excluding nonprogrammed externally-financed investment 
projects  (see  below).  The  deterioration  in  the  deficit  target  relative  to  the  1%  of  GDP  budget 
objective is due to the fact that revenue is projected to be significantly lower than the projection 
in  the  budget,  reflecting  the  contraction  in  economic  activity,  particularly  the  downturn  in 
revenue-generating  sectors  such  as  mining.  As  discussed  below,  the  revenue  shortfall  will  be 
offset in part by restrained spending and some tax policy measures. 
 
14. 
On spending, we plan to restrict non-priority expenditure, while protecting social outlays 
and  allowing  for  higher  investment  as  foreign  financing  materializes.  To  this  end,  we  expect 
substantial savings on nonessential spending and areas where execution has been slow. At the 
same time, we intend to boost spending on social protection programs, and are in discussions 
with partners, notably the World Bank, on how to strengthen these programs. 
 
Our  aim  is  to  restrict  spending  financed  by  domestic  resources  and  instead  rely  on 
15. 
external  financing  to  fund  the  increase  in  capital  spending.  We  expect  additional  resources  to 
become available from external donors and partners on top of what is currently projected by the 
IMF.  While  much  of  these  resources  are  only  partially  concessional,  they  would  allow  us  to 
finance more public investment projects, and potentially set up credit lines for small and medium 
enterprises.  To  this  end,  we  propose  to  spend  up  to  $200  million  from  those  additional 
resources  on  public  investment  in  2009,  which  would  allow  us  to  increase  our  deficit  target 
accordingly.  We  are  committed  to  maintaining  transparency  in  the  use  of  such  resources  by 
channeling any additional spending through the budget. We will also limit the use of government 
cash deposits to finance the budget, as we recognize the need to have a cushion for cash-flow 
management purposes, and possibly for future needs. 
 
16.  We are implementing some changes to tax policy. Given the weak revenue outlook and 
the  difficult conditions  facing  Armenian  firms  with  respect  to  trading  partners,  we  plan  to  raise 
temporarily  customs  tariffs  for  some  goods.  We  recognize  the  distortionary  impact  of  such  a 
policy, and the negative impact on the poor. However, the changes in tariff rates are within our 
commitments to the WTO, and will be limited to a certain number of goods for which Armenian 
substitutes exist. In terms of revenue impact, we expect this measure to generate an additional 
AMD10  billion  in  receipts  in  2009.  In  addition,  we  have  recently  raised  presumptive  taxes  on 
tobacco  products,  we  plan  to  raise  excise  taxes  on  imported  alcoholic  beverages,  and  are 
considering raising presumptive taxes on petroleum products. Looking forward, we maintain our 
objective of abolishing presumptive taxation for tobacco and fuel, and to this end, we will submit 
legislation to parliament by December 2009 to bring petroleum and tobacco products within the 
regular tax regimes (excise tax, customs duties, profit tax, and value-added tax [VAT]), effective 
1 January 2011.
